article.paragraph: Boudica(IPAc-enˈbuːdɨkə; alternative spelling:Boudicca, also known asBoadiceaIPAc-enboʊdɨˈsiːəand inWelsh languageWelshaslangcyBuddugIPA-cyˈbɨ̞ðɨ̞ɡ)Cite book[[John Davies (historian)|John Davies]]A History of WalesPenguin1993London280-14-014581-8(d. AD 60 or 61) was a queen of theBritons (historical)BritishIcenitribe who led an uprising against the occupying forces of theRoman Empire.

Boudica's husbandPrasutagusruled as a nominally independent ally of Rome and left his kingdom jointly to his daughters and theRoman emperorin his will. However, when he died, his will was ignored and the kingdom was annexed. Boudica was flogged, her daughterswartime sexual violenceraped, and Roman financiers called in their loans.

In AD 60 or 61, when theGovernors of Roman BritainRoman governorGaius Suetonius Paulinuswas campaigning on the island ofAngleseyoff the northwest coast ofWales, Boudica led the Iceni, theTrinovantesand others in revolt.cite bookRichard Hingley and Christina UnwinBoudica: Iron Age Warrior QueenHambledon ContinuumNew Edition15 June 2006978-1-85285-516-144 and 61They destroyedlangla[[Camulodunum]](modernColchester), earlier the capital of theTrinovantesbut at that time alangla[[colonia (Roman)|colonia]], a settlement for discharged Roman soldiers, and site of a temple to the former EmperorClaudius. Upon hearing of the revolt, Suetonius hurried tolangla[[Londinium]](modernLondon), the twenty-year-old commercial settlement that was the rebels' next target.

The Romans, having concluded that they did not have the numbers to defend the settlement, evacuated and abandonedlanglaLondinium. Boudica led 100,000 Iceni, Trinovantes and others to fightlangla[[Legio IX Hispana|Legio IX ''Hispana'']]and burned and destroyedlanglaLondinium, andlangla[[Verulamium]](modern-daySt Albans).cite bookN. DaviesThe Isles: A History200893cite bookS. Dando-CollinsLegions of Rome: The definitive history of every Roman legion2012An estimated 70,00080,000 Romans and British were killed in the three cities by those led by Boudica.Tacitus,Annals (Tacitus)Annals14.33Suetonius, meanwhile, regrouped his forces in theWest Midlands (region)West Midlands, and despite being heavily outnumbered, defeated the Britons in theBattle of Watling Street.

The crisis caused the EmperorNeroto consider withdrawing all Roman forces from Britain, but Suetonius's eventual victory over Boudica confirmed Roman control of the province. Boudica then either killed herself so she would not be captured, or fell ill and died. The extant sources,TacitusTacitus,langla[[Agricola (book)|Agricola]]Wikisource:Agricola#1414-16;Annals14:29-39andCassius Dio, differ.Cassius Dio,Roman History62:1-12

Interest in these events revived in theEnglish Renaissanceand led to Boudica's fame in theVictorian era.cite bookThe Gentleman's Magazinehttp://books.google.com/books?id1854W. Pickering541–Boudica has remained an importantcultural iconcultural symbolin theUnited Kingdom. However, the absence of native British literature during the early part of the first millennium means that knowledge of Boudica's rebellion comes solely from the writings of the Romans.
article.heading: History
Boudica's name
article.paragraph: Boudica has been known by several versions of her name.Raphael Holinshedcalls herVoadicia, whileEdmund Spensercalls herBunduca, a version of the name that was used in the popular Jacobean playBonduca, in 1612.Francis BeaumontandJohn Fletcher (playwright)John Fletcher,BonducaWilliam Cowper's poem,Boadicea, an ode(1782) popularised an alternative version of the name.William Cowper,Boadicea, an odeFrom the 19th century and much of the late 20th century,Boadiceawas the most common version of the name, which is probably derived from a mistranscription when a manuscript ofTacituswas copied in theMiddle Ages.

Her name was clearly spelledBoudiccain the best manuscripts of Tacitus, but alsolanggrcΒουδουικα,langgrcΒουνδουικα, andlanggrcΒοδουικαin the (later and probably secondary)epitomeofCassius Dio. The name is attested in inscriptions asBoudicainLusitania,BoudigainBordeaux, andBodiccainAlgeria.cite bookGraham WebsterBoudica: The British Revolt against Rome AD 601978cite book[[Guy de la Bédoyère]]http://www.romanbritain.freeserve.co.uk/Legions.htmThe Roman Army in Britain5 July 2005

Kenneth H. JacksonKenneth Jacksonconcludes, based on later development of Welsh and Irish, that the name derives from theProto-Celtic languageProto-Celticfeminine adjective*boudk, "victorious", that in turn is derived from theCeltic languagesCelticword*boud, "victory" (cf.Irish languageIrishlanggabua(Classical Irishlangghcbuadh),Buaidheach,Welsh languageWelshlangcybuddugoliaeth), and that the correct spelling of the name inCommon Brittonic(the British Celtic language) isBoudica, pronouncedIPA-celbɒʊˈdiːkaː.

The closest English equivalent to the vowel in the first syllable is theowin "bow-and-arrow".cite journal[[Kenneth H. Jackson|Kenneth Jackson]]Queen Boudica?Britannia10197925510.2307/526060The modern English pronunciation isIPAc-enˈbuːdɪkə,Boudicca. Dictionary.com. Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.1). article.heading: Background

article.paragraph: Tacitus and Dio agree that Boudica was ofroyal familyroyaldescent. Dio describes her as "possessed of greater intelligence than often belongs to women." He also describes her as tall, withtawny (color)tawnyhair hanging down to below her waist, a harsh voice and a piercing glare. He notes that she habitually wore a large golden necklace (perhaps atorc), a colourful tunic, and a thick cloak fastened by abrooch.cite webhttp://www.academia.edu/548341/Boudica_Cartimandua_Messalina_and_Agrippina_the_Younger._Independent_Women_of_Power_and_the_Gendered_Rhetoric_of_Roman_HistoryBoudica, Cartimandua, Messalina and Agrippina the Younger. Independent Women of Power and the Gendered Rhetoric of Roman HistoryPeter Keeganacademia.eduThe termlanggrc-Latnxanthotrichostranslated in this passage as redbrown or tawny can also mean auburn, or a shadeshortof brown, but most translators now agree a colour in between light and browny redtawnycite bookBoudica and her stories: narrative transformations of a warrior queenCarolyn D. WilliamsUniversity of Delaware Press200962

Her husbandPrasutaguswas the king of theIceni, the people who inhabited roughly what is nowNorfolk. They initially were not part of the territory under direct Roman control, having voluntarily allied themselves to Rome followingClaudius'sRoman conquest of Britainconquestof AD 43. They were proud of their independence, and had revolted in AD 47 when the then-governorPublius Ostorius Scapulathreatened to disarm them.Tacitus,Annals12:31-32Prasutagus had lived a long life of conspicuous wealth and, hoping to preserve his line, made theRoman emperorco-heir to his kingdom, along with his wife and two daughters.

It was normal Roman practice to allow allied kingdoms their independence only for the lifetime of theirclient king, who would then agree to leave his kingdom to Rome in his will. For example, the provinces ofBithyniacite book[[Howard Hayes Scullard]]From the Gracchi to Nero198290andGalatiacite bookJohnMorrisLondinium: London in the Roman Empire1982107–108were incorporated into the Empire in just this way.Roman lawalso allowedinheritanceonly through the male line, so when Prasutagus died, his attempts to preserve his line were ignored and his kingdom was annexed as if it had been conquered. His lands and property were confiscated and nobles treated like slaves. According toTacitus, Boudica was flogged and her daughters were raped. Cassius Dio says that Roman financiers, includingSeneca the Younger, chose this time to call in their loans. Tacitus does not mention this, but does single out the RomanpromagistrateprocuratorCatus Decianusfor criticism for his "avarice".
article.heading: Boudica's uprising
article.paragraph: In AD 60 or 61, while the current governor,Gaius Suetonius Paulinus, was leading a campaign against the island oflanglaMona(modernAnglesey) in the north of Wales, which was a refuge for British rebels and a stronghold of thedruids, the Iceni conspired with their neighbours the Trinovantes, amongst others, to revolt. Boudica was chosen as their leader. According to Tacitus, they drew inspiration from the example ofArminius, the prince of theCherusciwho had driven the Romans out of Germany in AD 9, and their own ancestors who had drivenJulius Caesarfrom Britain.Tacitus,langlaAgricolaWikisource:Agricola#1515Dio says that at the outset Boudica employed a form ofdivination, releasing aharefrom the folds of her dress and interpreting the direction in which it ran, and invokedAndraste, a BritishgoddessofVictoria (mythology)victory.

The rebels' first target waslangla[[Camulodunum#Iceni Revolt|Camulodunum]](Colchester), the former Trinovantian capital and, at that time, a Romanlangla[[colonia (Roman)|colonia]]. The Roman veterans who had been settled there mistreated the locals and a temple to the former emperorClaudiushad been erected there at local expense, making the city a focus for resentment. The Roman inhabitants sought reinforcements from the procurator, Catus Decianus, but he sent only two hundredauxiliaries (Roman military)auxiliary troops. Boudica's army fell on the poorly defended city and destroyed it, besieging the last defenders in the temple for two days before it fell.ArchaeologyArchaeologistshave shown that the city was methodically demolished.cite newsJason Burkehttp://observer.guardian.co.uk/uk_news/story/0,6903,406152,00.htmlDig uncovers Boudicca's brutal streak[[The Observer]]3 December 2000The future governorQuintus Petillius Cerialis, then commanding theLegio IX HispanaLegio IX ''Hispana'', attempted to relieve the city, but suffered anMassacre of the Ninth Legionoverwhelming defeat. His infantry was wiped outonly the commander and some of his cavalry escaped. The location of this famous destruction of thelanglaLegio IXis now claimed by some to be the village ofGreat Wratting, in Suffolk, which lies in the Stour Valley on the Icknield Way West of Colchester, and by a village in Essex.Cite webHaverhill From the Iron Age to 1899http://www.stedmundsbury.gov.uk/sebc/visit/hh-to-1899.cfmSt. Edmundsbury Borough CouncilAfter this defeat, Catus Decianus fled toGaul.

When news of the rebellion reached him, Suetonius hurried alongWatling Streetthrough hostile territory tolanglaLondinium.langlaLondiniumwas a relatively new settlement, founded after the conquest of AD 43, but it had grown to be a thriving commercial centre with a population of travellers, traders, and, probably, Roman officials. Suetonius considered giving battle there, but considering his lack of numbers and chastened by Petillius's defeat, decided to sacrifice the city to save the province.

paragraph.extension: Alarmed by this disaster and by the fury of the province which he had goaded into war by his rapacity, the procurator Catus crossed over into Gaul. Suetonius, however, with wonderful resolution, marched amidst a hostile population to Londinium, which, though undistinguished by the name of a colony, was much frequented by a number of merchants and trading vessels. Uncertain whether he should choose it as a seat of war, as he looked round on his scanty force of soldiers, and remembered with what a serious warning the rashness of Petilius had been punished, he resolved to save the province at the cost of a single town. Nor did the tears and weeping of the people, as they implored his aid, deter him from giving the signal of departure and receiving into his army all who would go with him. Those who were chained to the spot by the weakness of their sex, or the infirmity of age, or the attractions of the place, were cut off by the enemy.Tacitus

article.paragraph: Londinium was abandoned to the rebels who burnt it down, slaughtering anyone who had not evacuated with Suetonius. Archaeology shows a thick red layer of burnt debris covering coins and pottery dating before AD 60 within the bounds of Roman Londinium;cite bookGeorge Patrick WelchBritannia: The Roman Conquest & Occupation of Britain1963107whilst Roman-era skulls found in theWalbrookin 2013 were potentially linked to victims of the rebels.cite webhttp://www.theguardian.com/science/2013/oct/02/roman-skulls-crossrail-london-boudiccaRoman skulls found during Crossrail dig in London may be Boudicca victimsMaev Kennedy[[The Guardian]]langla[[Verulamium]](St Albans) was next to be destroyed.

In the three settlements destroyed, between seventy and eighty thousand people are said to have been killed. Tacitus says that the Britons had no interest in taking or selling prisoners, only in slaughter bygibbet, fire, or cross. Dio's account gives more detail; that the noblest women were impaled on spikes and had their breasts cut off and sewn to their mouths, "to the accompaniment of sacrifices, banquets, and wanton behaviour" in sacred places, particularly the groves of Andraste.
article.heading: Romans rally

link.part: ''Boadicea and Her Daughters'' byThomas Thornycroft, standing nearWestminster Millennium PierWestminster Pier, London

article.paragraph: While Boudica's army continued their assault in Verulamium (St. Albans), Suetonius regrouped his forces. According to Tacitus, he amassed a force including his ownLegio XIV GeminaLegio XIV ''Gemina'', somevexillationes(detachments) of theLegio XX Valeria VictrixXX ''Valeria Victrix'', and any available auxiliaries.Tacitus,Annals14.34Theprefectoflangla[[Legio II Augusta|Legio II ''Augusta'']],Poenius Postumus, stationed nearExeter, ignored the call,Tacitus,Annals14.37and a fourth legion,langla[[Legio IX Hispana|IX ''Hispana'']], had been routed trying to relievelanglaCamulodunum,Tacitus,Annals14.32but nonetheless the governor was able to call on almost ten thousand men.

Suetonius took a stand at an unidentified location, probably in theWest Midlands (region)West Midlandssomewhere along theRoman roadnow known asWatling Street, in adefile (geography)defilewith a wood behind him  but his men were heavily outnumbered. Dio says that, even if they were lined up one deep, they would not have extended the length of Boudica's line. By now the rebel forces were said to have numbered 230,000, however, this number should be treated with scepticism  Dio's account is known only from a lateepitome, and ancient sources commonly exaggerate enemy numbers.

Boudica exhorted her troops from herchariot, her daughters beside her. Tacitus gives her a short speech in which she presents herself not as anaristocracy (class)aristocratavenging her lost wealth, but as an ordinary person, avenging her lost freedom, her battered body, and the abused chastity of her daughters. She said their cause was just, and the deities were on their side; the one legion that had dared to face them had been destroyed. She, a woman, was resolved to win or die; if the men wanted to live in slavery, that was their choice.

However, the lack of manoeuvrability of the British forces, combined with lack of open-field tactics to command these numbers, put them at a disadvantage to the Romans, who were skilled at open combat due to their superior equipment and discipline. Also, the narrowness of the field meant that Boudica could put forth only as many troops as the Romans could at a given time.

First, the Romans stood their ground and used volleys oflangla[[pilum|pila]](heavy javelins) to kill thousands of Britons who were rushing toward the Roman lines. The Roman soldiers, who had now used up theirlanglapila, were then able to engage Boudica's second wave in the open. As the Romans advanced in aflying wedgewedgeformation, the Britons attempted to flee, but were impeded by the presence of their own families, whom they had stationed in a ring of wagons at the edge of the battlefield, and were slaughtered. This is not the first instance of this tactic the women of theCimbri, in theBattle of VercellaeagainstGaius Marius, were stationed in a line of wagons and acted as a last line of defence.Florus,Epitome of Roman HistoryWikisource:Epitome of Roman History/Book 1#381.38Ariovistusof theSuebiis reported to have done the same thing in his battle againstJulius Caesar.Julius Caesar,langla[[Commentarii de Bello Gallico]]Wikisource:Commentaries on the Gallic War/Book1#511.51Tacitus reports that "according to one report almost eighty thousand Britons fell" compared with only four hundred Romans.

File:Boudicca Statue.pngthumbBoadicea, front viewThomas ThornycroftAccording to Tacitus in hisAnnals, Boudica poisoned herself, though in thelanglaAgricolawhich was written almost twenty years prior he mentions nothing of suicide and attributes the end of the revolt tolanglasocordia("indolence"); Dio says she fell sick and died and then was given a lavish burial; though this may be a convenient way to remove her from the story. Considering Dio must have read Tacitus, it is worth noting he mentions nothing about suicide (which was also how Postumus and Nero ended their lives).

Postumus, on hearing of the Roman victory, fell on his sword.Catus Decianus, who had fled to Gaul, was replaced byGaius Julius Alpinus Classicianus. Suetonius conducted punitive operations, but criticism by Classicianus led to an investigation headed byNero'sfreedmanPolyclitus (freedman)Polyclitus. Fearing Suetonius's actions would provoke further rebellion, Nero replaced the governor with the more conciliatoryPublius Petronius Turpilianus.Tacitus,Annalswikisource:The Annals (Tacitus)/Book 14#3914.39The historianSuetoniusGaius Suetonius Tranquillustells us the crisis had almost persuaded Nero to abandon Britain.Suetonius,Nero18,39-40
article.heading: Location of her defeat
article.paragraph: The location of Boudica's defeat is unknown. Most historianscitation neededMarch 2014favour a site in theWest Midlands (county)West Midlands, somewhere along the Roman road now known asWatling Street. Kevin K. Carroll suggests a site close toHigh Cross, LeicestershireHigh CrossinLeicestershire, on the junction of Watling Street and theFosse Way, which would have allowed thelangla[[Legio II Augusta|Legio II ''Augusta'']], based atExeter, to rendezvous with the rest of Suetonius's forces, had they not failed to do so.cite journalKevin K. CarrollThe Date of Boudicca's RevoltBritannia101979197–20210.2307/526056Manduessedum(Mancetter), near the modern town ofAtherstoneinWarwickshire, has also been suggested,cite book[[Sheppard Frere]]Britannia: A History of Roman Britain198773as has "The Rampart" nearMessinginEssex, according to legend.cite webMessing-cum-Inworth Community Websitehttp://messing-cum-inworth-pc.gov.uk/messVill.htmMessing VillageMore recently, a discovery of Roman artefacts inKings Nortonclose toBirmingham military historyMetchley Camphas suggested another possibility,cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/west_midlands/5016126.stmIs Boudicca buried in Birmingham?[[BBC News Online]]25 May 20069 September 2006and a thorough examination of a stretch of Watling Street between St. Albans, Boudica's last known location, and the Fosse Way junction has suggested the Cuttle Mill area ofPaulerspuryin Northamptonshire, which hastopographyvery closely matching that described by Tacitus of the scene of the battle.cite webhttp://paulerspury.org/content/view/18/49/ﾓﾊﾞｲﾙ版paulerspury.orgdead linkOctober 2015

In 2009 it was suggested that the Iceni were returning to East Anglia along theIcknield Waywhen they encountered the Roman army in the vicinity ofArbury Banks, HertfordshireArbury Bank, Hertfordshire.cite journalGrahame Appleby2009The Boudican Revolt: Countdown to DefeatHertfordshire Archaeology and History1657–66http://www.researchgate.net/publication/280564223_The_Boudican_Revolt_Countdown_to_defeatIn March 2010, evidence was published suggesting the site may be located atChurch Stowe, Northamptonshire.cite webhttp://www.craftpegg.com/Battle_Church_Stowe_CP.pdfPDFLandscape Analysis and Appraisal Church Stowe, Northamptonshire, as a Candidate Site for the Battle of Watling Streetcraftpegg.com
article.heading: Historical sources
article.paragraph: Tacitus, the most important Roman historian of this period, took a particular interest in Britain as his father-in-lawGnaeus Julius Agricolaserved there three times (and was the subject of his first book). Agricola was a military tribune under Suetonius Paulinus, which almost certainly gave Tacitus an eyewitness source for Boudica's revolt. Cassius Dio's account is only known from anepitome, and his sources are uncertain. He is generally agreed to have based his account on that of Tacitus, but he simplifies the sequence of events and adds details, such as the calling in of loans, that Tacitus does not mention.

Gildas, in his 6th centurylangla[[De Excidio et Conquestu Britanniae]], may have been alluding to Boudica when he wrote "A treacherous lioness butchered the governors who had been left to give fuller voice and strength to the endeavours of Roman rule".
article.heading: Cultural depictions
History and literature
article.paragraph: By theMiddle AgesBoudica was forgotten. She makes no appearance inBede's work, thelangla[[Historia Brittonum]], thelangcy[[Mabinogion]]orGeoffrey of Monmouth'sHistory of the Kings of Britain. But the rediscovery of the works of Tacitus during the Renaissance allowedPolydore Vergilto reintroduce her into British history as "Voadicea" in 1534.cite bookPolydore Vergil's English History, Book 2https://books.google.co.uk/books?id69–72Raphael Holinshed also included her story in hisChronicles(1577), based on Tacitus and Dio,Raphael Holinshed,Chronicles: History of England4.9-13and inspiredWilliam ShakespeareShakespeare'syounger contemporariesFrancis BeaumontandJohn Fletcher (playwright)John Fletcherto write a play,Bonduca, in 1610.William Cowperwrote a popular poem, "Boadicea, an ode", in 1782.

It was in theVictorian erathat Boudica's fame took on legendary proportions asQueen Victoriacame to be seen as Boudica's "namesake", their names being identical in meaning. Victoria'sPoet Laureate,Alfred, Lord Tennyson, wrote a poem, "Boadicea", and several ships were namedHMS Boadiceaafter her.Alfred, Lord Tennyson,Boadicea

article.paragraph: mainBoadicea and Her DaughtersA statue ofBoadicea and Her DaughtersBoudica with her daughtersin herwar chariot(ahistorically furnished withscythed chariotscythesafter theAchaemenid EmpirePersianfashion) was executed byThomas Thornycroftover the 1850s and 1860s with the encouragement ofPrince Albert, Prince ConsortPrince Albert, who lent his horses for the model.cite bookImages of Women in Peace & War: Cross-Cultural & Historical Perspectiveshttps://books.google.co.uk/books?id53Macmillan Press1987LondonBoadicea: Warrior, Mother, and MythMacdonaldSharon0-299-11764-2Thornycroft exhibited the head separately in 1864. It was cast in bronze in 1902, 17 years after Thornycroft's death, by his sonJohn Isaac ThornycroftSir John, who presented it to theLondon County Council. They erected it on a plinth on theVictoria Embankmentnext toWestminster Bridgeand thePalace of WestminsterHouses of Parliament, inscribed with the following lines from Cowper's poem:

extension.extension: Regions Caesar never knewThy posterity shall sway.

article.paragraph: Ironically, the great anti-imperialist rebel was now identified with the head of theBritish Empire, and her statueCite webhttp://www.culture24.org.uk/history+%2526+heritage/war+%2526+conflict/pre%252d20th+century+conflict/tra22669Battlefield Britain — Boudicca's revolt against the RomansCorinne Field30 April 2006Culture248 December 2009stood guard over the city she razed to the ground.cite bookGraham WebsterBoudica: The British Revolt against Rome AD 601978
article.heading: Boudica and King's Cross
article.paragraph: The area ofKing's Cross, Londonwas previously a village known as Battle Bridge which was an ancient crossing of theRiver Fleet. The original name of the bridge was Broad Ford Bridge.

The name "Battle Bridge" led to a tradition that this was the site of a major battle between the Romans and the Iceni tribe led by Boudica.cite webhttp://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compidHighbury, Upper Holloway and King's CrossOld and New London: Volume 2Walter ThornburyGeorge Walter Thornbury1878273–27911 November 2010British History OnlineThe tradition is not supported by any historical evidence and is rejected by modern historians. However,Lewis Spence's 1937 bookBoadicea warrior queen of the Britonswent so far as to include a map showing the positions of the opposing armies. There is a belief that she was buried between platforms 9 and 10 inLondon King's Cross railway stationKing's Cross stationin London, England. There is no evidence for this and it is probably a post-World War IIinvention.cite webThe "Warrior Queen" under Platform 9http://www.museumoflondon.org.uk/English/Learning/Learningonline/features/roman/roman_london_7.htmhttp://web.archive.org/web/20090301192533/http://www.museumoflondon.org.uk/English/Learning/Learningonline/features/roman/roman_london_7.htmMuseum of London1 March 200913 August 2011

She appears as a playable character in real-time strategy mobile gameWorld of Warriors.
